1. Put options: Buying put options gives you the right to sell a stock or an index at a predetermined price, known as the strike price, within a specified time frame. If the market falls below the strike price, you can exercise the option and sell the underlying asset at the higher price, thereby limiting your losses.

2. Futures contracts: A futures contract is an agreement to buy or sell an asset at a future date at a predetermined price. You can enter into a short futures position, where you agree to sell the underlying asset at a certain price in the future. If the market falls, the value of your short position will rise, offsetting the losses from your underlying asset.

3. Protective puts: This strategy involves holding a long position in a stock and simultaneously buying put options on the same stock. If the stock price falls, the gain from the put option will offset the losses from the stock.

4. Collars: A collar is created by holding a long position in a stock, buying a put option at a lower strike price, and selling a call option at a higher strike price. This limits both the potential gains and losses of the stock position, creating a safety net in case of a market downturn.
